utterances: We'll still be in Afghanistan...couldn't be.
The broader point, though, about the president's appetite for war.
Yes, 50,000 soldiers still in Iraq, a hundred thousand now in Afghanistan.
And yes, a new war in Libya.
But he said - and I think quite rightly - there's going to be a timeline in both of those cases for withdrawal.
And you know, he signed up for this when he ran for office.
It includes commander-in-chief, and he said he was going to devote the resources necessary to the Afghan War, and he has done that, as you point out, tripling the force, making quite a commitment.
But as General Petraeus, the commander there, just testified recently, there are gains, but it's fragile and reversible.
Now, when something is fragile and reversible, that is not a solid win.
That is not a stable situation.
So it's difficult, but this is Obama facing the reality of being commander-in-chief when you're in two wars.
Bob Woodward, thanks as always very much for your time today.
Got a -working on a new one?
Trying.
Bob Woodward's most recent book is ""Obama's Wars."" He might have to pluralize his plurals for his next one.
He joined us here in Studio 3-A.
When we come back, we're going to be focusing on the disaster in Japan and the importance of ritual there.
So many people died in the quake and the tsunami.
The country is now struggling to bury its dead with appropriate respect.
Stay with us.
I'm Neal Conan.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
I'm Farai Chideya.
On today's Roundtable, the U.N.
sanctions North Korea, and Senator Lieberman gets an apology for an attack on his civil rights record.

Silva Storai is a small, fiery Italian woman in her early 40s.
She has several passions in life.
One of them is riding around the lanes of south India on a Royal Enfield motorcycle.
Another is racing horses.
She's one of the women blazing the trail in Bangalore.
At the beginning, it was difficult mostly because it's such a competitive field.
So I saw it different from my point of view being a woman.
If you win, the horse is good, and if you lose, you are not good enough.
So that's the way they see me.
Storai, who came to India 20 years ago, has become one of India's top women jockeys.
True, there aren't many, but she's also led the way in setting up the country's first female racing syndicates.
She believes women can overhaul the sport's rather tawdry image.
The way they look at racing is completely different.
It's fun, it's colorful and much more sporting.
The horse win where they put the money or they didn't put the money; it doesn't matter.

Like, you know, you still halfway to go and they're already cheering you on.

JUDY BEDEPAR(ph) (Former Stage Actress): We're none of us gamblers.
I mean, we trembled to put a hundred apiece because we think that brings bad luck to our horse.
Former stage actress Judy Bedepar always wanted to be the owner of a racehorse.
So when Indian racing rules changed several years ago to allow syndicates of up to 10 people, which made owning a racehorse more affordable, she was among the first women to sign up.
You buy this with your own money.
You don't get your husband's money.
So you got to be female, you got to love horses and you got to use your own money.
So if you lose your own money, your husband's not breathing down your neck.
So we're completely footloose and fancy-free where the money is concerned.
It's not a big amount, you see.
So it's, `Big deal.'
Trainer Iafan Gatala(ph) is the only male involved in the women syndicates.
With a new season approaching, he keeps a close eye on one of their more promising horses.
That's him.
That's Sandocran(ph).
He's a very strong little fellow.
He likes to gallop.
Iafan says he's delighted to have the female owners in his stable.
The women tend to say they're involved in horse racing for fun rather than for winning, but he disputes this.
They do, actually.
They love to win.
They start screaming the moment the horse jumps out from the gate.
So, OK, I mean, they want to win, everybody wants to win.
It's a sport.
Everybody including Silva.
In 2003, she became the first woman in Indian racing history to win a derby.
And then in 2004, she won another one.
I was losing till the last 50 meter, and then I realized--hey, my horse was inching on to him, but it wasn't quick enough.
So the last 50 meter, I just screamed, like, `Go!

It was funny.
Silva says this victory did much to win over the local racing fans to the idea that women do have a place at the racetrack.

Two months after Hurricane Katrina devastated the Mississippi Gulf Coast, schools in the communities of Bay St. Louis and Waveland still have not been able to reopen.
The two towns are considered ground zero, the area hardest hit by Katrina's winds and 28-foot storm surge.
Two of the local schools were destroyed and others suffered significant damage.
When classes finally do resume, many will be held in portable classrooms.
In the meantime, dozens of children in the two towns are attending classes and are seeing friends again in tent schools.
NPR's David Schaper reports.
Ten-year-old Britney Brown(ph) says being out of class for the last two months since Katrina destroyed her Bay St. Louis school really hasn't been too bad.
I don't miss school at all because I'm really not a school person.
But her mother, Nicole Brown, takes a different view and says this is what she needs.
A break.
No, I'm ready for school to start.
I'm tired.
You know, they're bored and they need something normal to do for a change.
Something normal like a reading lesson.

Well, there is two parts to that.
There's his ideas and how long it took his ideas to get accepted.
And I think both of those are important parts of the story.
Judah was a pediatric surgeon and he was very impressed -operating on tumors in children - how vascular they were.

And the tumors had a very rich blood supply and not only that, but that the blood vessels seem to come in from a lot of different directions where, normally, organs get a very discreet well-defined blood supply usually from a single vessel.

And he thought that maybe the answer to cancer was not to attack the cancer cell itself, but rather to attack the cancer's blood supply, and started to study why cancers induced this abnormal blood vessel growth.
And that led over many decades into the field that we have today.
If you'd like to join our conversation, our telephone number is 800-989-8255.
That's 800-989-TALK.
And if you want more information about our topics this hour, you can go to the Web site, www.sciencefriday.com where you'll find links to our topic.

So going back to this question of this blood supply, I mean, if tumors have this increased blood supply, it - I mean, maybe this is the benefit of 20/20 hindsight, but if you say, well, if we can cut off the blood supply, maybe we can, you know, destroy the tumor, doesn't seem like that far-out of an idea.
Well, a lot of things seem obvious after they're established.
Right.
I think that's the essence of a lot of things in science.

The important part of that is that cancer specialists, both clinically and in the laboratory, were intensely focused on the cancer cell being the primary problem and attention to not only just the cancer cell, but a particular aspect of the cancer cell, which is, its mitotic division, the division of the cancer cells.
And that has - that led to an awful lot of research concerning abnormalities and mitosis, and led to 99.9 percent of the drugs we now have to treat cancer, drugs that basically attack mitosis.

So considering that the problem with cancer may not just be the cell itself, but its relationship to its environment, and the blood vessels being a component of that environment, that was not in the mainstream of thought, and therefore, it was not pursued.
